title-group.article-title: Analysing China’s economic interdependence and political relations with its neighbours

author-notes.corresp: James R. Masterson, Department of Government, Morehead State University, 114A Combs Building, 150 University Ave. Morehead, KY 40351, USA Email: j.masterson@moreheadstate.edu

abstract.p: This study examines the effects that economic interdependence has on political relations between China and its neighbours. Three economic liberal hypotheses are tested using data from the International Cooperation and Regional Conflicts dataset to measure dyadic political interaction along with economic data from the IMF and China Statistical Yearbooks and control variable data from Polity IV, COW CINC, among other sources. Though a significant amount of literature addresses the effects trade has on conflict at the systemic level, few studies address it at the dyadic level and even fewer test the pacification of trade on non-Western states. Examining economic, political, institutional, geographical, and political relations data from 1987 to 2001, this research tests the economic liberal hypothesis which posits that interdependence is associated with cooperative political relations between states. The findings show that trade interdependence is generally associated with political cooperation. However, the realist contention that relative power increases are associated with political conflict is also supported and analysed further.

body.p: China’s foreign relations in the post-Mao era have been characterized as expanding interactions with the outside world through trade and investment liberalization and participation in international institutions. Certainly many scholars have written about such Chinese positioning in the world, but there is also convincing evidence to support these claims.1 One aspect of China’s rise is the influence of these economic linkages on China’s political relations with its neighbours. Lampton and Brzezinski argue that China’s rise is likely to be peaceful because of the extensive economic linkages it has with the West and its Asian neighbours.2 Others, such as Mearsheimer, from looking at the rise of previous great powers, find the path to great power status to be violent, citing great wars fought over the inability of major powers in the international system to accommodate rising states.3 This research examines how economic interdependence affects political relations between China and its neighbours. It finds, in contrast to realist expectations, that increases in economic interdependence between China and its neighbours are associated with improved political relations.

The death of Chinese leader Mao Zedong marked a change in direction for the Chinese government and people. In 1978, under the leadership of Deng Xiaoping, China began an era of reforms in what would eventually result in the dismantling of much of the Chinese socialist economy.4 China has opened itself to foreign investment and shifted its industrial strategy from energy-intensive heavy industry to less energy-intensive light industry concentrating on maximizing jobs particularly for the export economy.5 This strategy has played out well for China as its trade with the world has increased more than 4,500 per cent since 1980, outpacing all its neighbours. Chinese aggregated trade is more than 60 per cent of its gross domestic product (GDP), making it one of the most trade-dependent countries in the world. A second reason for analysing China’s foreign relations is that US policymakers, and the world as a whole, have been extremely concerned about its rise, particularly since admission into the WTO. At the time of reforms, China ranked 30th in world trade and has since risen to become the world’s second largest trading state in 2009. In 2006, China alone accounted for 11 per cent of growth in world trade.6 While international trade plays a significant role in China’s impressive economic growth, foreign direct investment (FDI) provides a valuable source of capital and employment. Chinese FDI levels in 1992, the year in which reforms entered a new phase, accounted for 75 per cent of China’s capital inflows.7 By 2006 this figure jumped to more than 93 per cent. Furthermore, China is the world’s second most valued destination for FDI behind the United States, after having surpassed the United States briefly in 2003.

To facilitate its economic integration into the global economy, China has changed course on its perceived utility of international institutions from the pre-reform era. In contrast to the ‘self-reliant’ policies of the Maoist era, China now has membership in a number of the most influential institutions. China’s early involvement in these institutions generally was geared towards its development. In the late 1990s, China’s participation in these and a growing number of institutions, both regional and global in scale, was to increase its influence in international economic issues and reduce US unilateralism in the region.8 For example, China joined the World Bank Group in 1980, providing it access to large-scale capital assistance. Similarly, in the early 1980s China developed a working relationship with the United Nations Development Programme requesting economic aid. China joined the Asian Development Bank in 1986, eventually becoming the institution’s fifth largest cumulative borrower and leading loan recipient in 1995.9 Worth noting are other important regional institutions of which China is a member: the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, Asia Regional Forum, and the Shanghai Cooperation Organization. Additionally, China is an active participant in the ASEAN Plus Three (APT) dialogue. Where Japan was formally rebuked by Washington for its Asian Monetary Fund plan, after the 1997–1998 Asian Financial Crisis, members of the APT dialogue agreed on a currency swap under the Chiang Mai agreement. This may well be the first steps towards a regional free trade agreement. Under this agreement, China, along with Japan and South Korea provide hard currencies to ASEAN developing economies in the event of a currency crisis.

As China prospered, its need for developmental resources and its availability to development aid from various international institutions declined. According to Feeney, the logical outgrowth of China’s modernization programme and deepening interdependence within the global economy has been Beijing’s long-term objective for joining the WTO.10 In 2001 China gained membership into the WTO. At this time, Moore characterized China ‘as being heavily involved with, but only shallowly integrated into, the world economy’.11

Economic reforms in China have resulted in greater levels of international trade and incoming FDI within China. This in turn has created conditions necessary for Chinese leaders to participate in a number of international institutions in order to influence policies associated with trade and financial flows. As China’s economy grew, its interests in these organizations changed. China has utilized a huge pool of lending capital in billions of dollars in grants, loans, and concessionary credits to cope with monetary and trade imbalances and to finance infrastructure projects.12 After years of participation, Feeney argues that these institutions have ‘enmeshed China more firmly into the international community and theoretically have raised the stakes against precipitous and ill-advised adventurism, especially in regards to Taiwan and the contested Spratly Islands in the South China Sea’.13

sec.title: Interdependence theory
sec.p: While there has been considerable theoretical and empirical work on economic interdependence theory since the Second World War, the results are still debatable. There are several propositions about the relationship between interdependence and conflict. The first proposition that will be discussed are two economic liberal arguments that trade promotes peace. The second is the neorealist argument that asymmetries in trade lead to conflict. The third argument is a bridge between the two neoliberal and neorealist claims based on the expectations of future trade. It claims that as the future expectations of trade diminish the likelihood of conflict increases. And lastly discussed is the claim by some neorealists which posits that trade relations have no independent effect on political relations.

Economic liberalism puts forward the notion that as states become more economically linked with each other, they will be less likely to solve international problems through the use of force.14 There are two separate arguments in the literature which address why this occurs. The first is the opportunity cost argument. Interdependent states are less likely to resort to the use of force because the additional benefits that interstate trade yields for each economy would be lost by a disruption in trade as a result of conflict. Loss in the benefits of trade can result in, among other things, lower national welfare, domestic tensions among groups that must adjust to the resulting trade dispute by finding a new, less efficient export market, and economic vulnerabilities should the economy find it difficult to replace the needed imported goods or sustain costly long-term economic restructuring. Therefore a disruption of trade can lead to a direct reduction in the state’s welfare.

Links between trade and peace have been argued by classic liberals for centuries. For liberals, such as Smith, people who pursue their self-interest also, by no intent of their own, promote the interests of society.15 Trade policies motivated by self-interest may lead to peaceful relations among actors because the cost of conflict increases. Thus, the unconditional liberal hypothesis posits that as states become more interdependent they are less likely to experience conflict between them. Work by Keohane and Nye shows that when states reach a level of complex interdependence there are multiple channels of contacts between the societies, there is no clear hierarchy of agenda issues between the states, and the use of military force to solve an interstate dispute is not an option.16 Furthermore, work by Rosecrance shows that as interdependence grows, states gain more efficiently what they need through trade rather than war; therefore states will opt for trading relations.17

The second argument is the costly signalling theory of liberal peace. As the theory goes, economic linkages between states can serve as a common basis for costly signalling.18 States can communicate information through these economic linkages. States inform competitors of their relative resolve when willing to risk economic harm in the pursuit of political objectives.19 Markets punish states that pursue actions that threaten economic returns. Leaders willing to endure these economic punishments signal their resolve while others unwilling to tolerate the economic costs have less resolve and bow out of the contest.

In contrast to liberal theories of interdependence and conflict, realist theory leads to a diametrically opposed result. Hirschman has stated that since the gains from trade do not accrue equally, a resulting imbalance can affect the relations between states.20 These shifting power relations are potentially a source of military confrontation.21 Waltz claims that since interdependence leads to increased closeness of contacts, it raises the prospect of at least occasional conflict. Thus, he asserts that the liberal myth is false.22

As a bridge between neoliberal and neorealist arguments, Copeland finds that as the expectations of future trade diminish the likelihood of conflict increases.23 Seeking to end the disagreements between the neoliberals and neorealists about the conditions prior to both Great Wars, Copeland introduces a new causal variable, the expectation of future trade. Examining the effects of economic interdependence simultaneously with those of the future expectations of trade, Copeland finds that economic interdependence can foster peace, as the liberals claim, but only to the extent that states perceive the expectations of future trade to be high. Realist claims are likely to hold if the expectations of future trade are low.

Finally, drawing from heightened levels of international trade prior to the outbreak of the First World War and low levels before it, realist scholars have shown that interdependence has no systematic effect on conflict. Conflict is largely a result of political–military relations, and power relations underlie any apparent effect interdependence may have on interstate relations.24

This research tests the liberal hypothesis on the case of China. Kang reminds us that many of the theories in international relations are inductively derived from European interactions of the past several hundred years.25 It is not clear whether these theories are generalizable to Asia given its very different political economy, history, culture, and demographics. Kang finds that these theories do a poor job when applied to Asia.

A dyadic study focused exclusively on China and its neighbours is needed for important theoretical and statistical reasons. Firstly the current literature on economic interdependence involving large N-studies largely incorporates time frames that do not account for dramatic international economic changes that have been recently occurring in China. Nearly all of these large N-studies report findings that based on averages of many states. However, this tells us little about how China behaves in particular, which is of critical importance to foreign policymakers.26

Furthermore, much of the current literature on Chinese foreign policy and interdependence is based on qualitative research.27 The studies provide rich analyses of how interdependence shapes and constrains Chinese foreign policy, but do not uncover a systematic relationship between levels of interdependence and political relations between China and its neighbours. An exception to this is Scott Kastner’s recent work explaining how conflict between China and Taiwan affects bilateral trade. This book, however, addresses the effects conflict has on interdependence.28

Aside from the statistical reasons addressed in the preceding, there are theoretical issues of interest that necessitate a study based exclusively on China’s dyadic interactions. Given the centrality of the debate on China’s rise in the foreign affairs of many great powers, this study aims to assess the extent to which economic interdependence theory holds to an approximate ‘least-likely’ case. China is a ‘least-likely’ case for two reasons. It is a relative latecomer to participation in the global economy and international institutions. Secondly, as a communist state, CCP leaders may be less receptive to societal pressures that push for foreign policies which interfere less with gains from international commercial linkages since there is no second political party to offer policy alternatives publicly. Therefore, it is important to examine whether interdependence theory holds for the China case. As Segal states, ‘There is little doubt that the single most important state in East Asia is China.’29

sec.title: Scope of research
sec.p: This research empirically tests the unconditional liberal hypothesis using data for China and 10 of its neighbours. For a state to be included in the analysis, several criteria needed to be satisfied. First, the state had to be contiguous with China, sharing either a land or water boundary (within 500 statutory miles) and outside of the control of the People’s Republic of China, thus excluding Hong Kong and Macao. Additionally, Taiwan is excluded from the sample because both governments in Taipei and Beijing believe in a ‘one China’ policy; therefore, relations with Taiwan are not considered ‘international’ but instead domestic. Second, the state needed at least two years of interstate political relation measures with China captured by the content analysis. As such, Afghanistan, Bhutan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Laos, Myanmar, and Tajikistan were excluded for lack of sufficient evidence of political relations with China.30 Lastly, the state had to have reliable economic data, given the limitations of data collection. The Democratic People’s Republic of Korea was excluded for this reason.

The study begins in 1987, almost a decade after China opened up; providing sufficient time for interdependencies to be created between China and its neighbours. While it is acknowledged that the study is limited in both time and geographical scope, it nevertheless contains important analysis not found elsewhere in the literature.

sec.title: Existing measures of interdependence
sec.p: The unit of observation for this study is a dyad – relations between two countries, namely, China and a neighbouring state. Monadic-level research finds support for trade interdependence reducing the likelihood of conflict.31 Similarly, recent research at the dyadic level finds that economic interdependence constrains the use of force between nations.32

While most of the research on the dyadic approach centres on trade indicators, more recent scholarship investigates the effects that financial measures such as FDI have on interstate conflict.33 For example, some scholars argue for the need to incorporate financial investment into any estimate of bilateral interdependence.34

Trade indicators as measurements of interdependence have been operationalized differently in the literature. Earlier measures were based on trade characteristics. Savage and Deutsch use exports to one trade partner as a percentage of total exports as an indicator of a state’s interdependence.35 Domke measures interdependence separately as a proportion of exports to GNP and exports to national income at the systemic level.36 Both of these measures only focus attention on exports as an indicator of interdependence. Imports are also a critical component of interdependence since states may import materials vital to their economic growth. Focusing on dyads, Polachek adopted the value of trade between partners as an indicator for interdependence.37 This approach is problematic because it does not take into account the relative size of an economy, an argument he made in later work.38 Interdependence between small economies that rely on a high proportion of trade relative to their GDP and their major trading partners’ is higher than large economies that rely on relatively low levels of trade. Oneal et al. measure interdependence as the value of dyadic trade as a proportion of GDP.39 This creates a continuous variable at the dyadic level, incorporates both aspects of trade, and adjusts for the size of a state’s economy. Later work by Oneal and Russett, however, use dyadic trade as a proportion of GDP as a measure for dyadic interdependence and adopt a weakest link approach by selecting the lower of the two ratios as the indicator for interdependence.40 Scholars have been critical of this operationalization on the grounds that it is not a dyadic measurement.41 Additionally, Barbieri challenges adjustments made only for the size of the economy. Instead, she argues that adjustment should also be based on the size of a state’s total trade because, unlike the pre-Second World War period, there is a high level of variation between GDP and total trade in the post-Second World War period. In an effort to understand the differences between the two measurements (one adjusting for GDP and the other for total trade) Barbieri’s research incorporates measurements of economic interdependence based on total trade in addition to GDP.42 Barbieri’s approach further differs from existing measurements in the literature because interdependence is measured as a geometric mean of the trade shares instead of as an arithmetic mean.

Several scholars have noted that an assessment of financial flows is crucial to the concept of economic interdependence. Unlike trade, which can be diverted during a disruption of trade flows between states, FDI is largely permanent and may actually be used against the home country should conflict ensue. For example, the United States seized German financial assets during both world wars and sold some of the seized companies, such as Bosch Magento, to investors to support the war effort. Currently 57 per cent of Chinese exports are created from foreign firms manufacturing in China, and China’s ratio of exports to GDP is more than three times greater than G-7 economies.43 To a large extent, China’s wealth is tied to FDI and exports and must foster conditions necessary for these to flourish. Investors are less likely to invest where instability exists.44 Conflict can be a major force of instability, thus reducing much needed FDI that provides materials for export to fuel China’s growth.

In sum, despite an evolution of the trade–conflict debate, there is little consensus about the most appropriate measurements for interdependence. This research adopts the measurement used by Oneal et al. for interdependence because it is a dyadic measurement that incorporates both aspects of trade, and it also controls for relative size of a nation’s economy (economy–trade interdependence). Additionally, as suggested by Barbieri, a second interdependence variable is created to adjust for the size of a state’s total trade (partner–trade interdependence).45 Because these two measurements are highly correlated, it is difficult to assess their independent effects on the dependent variable. Therefore, their effects are measured in separate models. Lastly, as financial flows have garnered much attention in the trade–conflict debate, coupled with the fact that China is a significant player in attracting shares of FDI, models presented here measure the separate effects that FDI may have on political relations.

sec.title: Hypotheses
sec.p: Do heightened levels of trade and financial interdependence improve political relations between China and its neighbours? This question represents the primary attempt of this research to empirically assess Chinese foreign relations. It will be tested against three hypotheses. Testing hypotheses is a central component in the pursuit of scientific discovery. Johnson suggests that in the area of Chinese foreign policy there is a dearth of empirical hypothesis testing.46 Introduced below are three hypotheses to answer the question just posed. The hypotheses are as follows:

list-item.p: Hyp. 1 As dyadic economy–trade interdependence increases, interstate political relations improve.
Hyp. 2 As dyadic partner–trade interdependence increases, interstate political relations improve.

sec.p: These are known as the unconditional liberal hypotheses. Much of the interdependence literature uses trade as the sole indicator of economic interdependence.47 Together these hypotheses take into account the different measurements that total trade-based interdependence yields. Comparison between the two hypotheses will allow an examination of how these different measurements may affect results. Barbieri similarly adopts this dual approach.48

list-item.p: Hyp. 3 As dyadic financial interdependence increases, interstate political relations improve.

sec.p: Recent research highlights the growing impact that FDI flows are creating. Rosecrance and Thompson show world FDI has increased 800 per cent since 1970, while trade levels have increased by half that.49 This research tests for the effects that FDI has on political relations between China and its neighbours.

sec.title: Research design
sec.p: In this study the dependent variable, interstate political relations, focuses exclusively on political events between China and its neighbours. To investigate whether economic interdependence creates a significant bond that deters states from experiencing a deterioration in political relations, the analysis is confined to the average level of political relations in a given year experienced between the two states which compose the dyad.

The unit of analysis for this research is a dyad-year; indicators for China and its neighbour for a given year. Values are recorded for the explanatory variables in a given year and for the dependent variable the following year. This study is limited to China and 10 of its neighbours, provided that the data for all variables is available. The final sample includes 150 dyadic years for the 15-year period 1987 to 2001; however, the actual sample size varies in each model depending on the number of cases with missing data. This variance results from four factors. First, some dyads do not have dependent variable data for all the years in the study. These cases are omitted. A second reason why actual samples sizes are smaller than the theoretical size is that some dyads have missing independent variable data. Trade data for South Korea is not available from 1987 to 1989. Lastly, some dyads have missing control variable data thus leaving them out of the sample for various years. In the end, results represent Chinese dyadic interactions with the following 10 states: Cambodia, India, Japan, Mongolia, Nepal, Pakistan, the Philippines, Russia, South Korea, and Vietnam.

In order to examine whether or not increasing levels of trade and financial interdependence have a pacifying effect on interstate relations, three separate linear regression models are estimated for the analysis of the dependent variable. The three models test the effects of the explanatory variables.50

Linear regression analysis will determine an estimated magnitude of the variables’ impact on the dependent variable, interstate political relations. Furthermore, this analysis determines whether sufficient likelihood exists to indicate that the estimates are indeed significant within a given confidence interval. Linear regression will also determine the explanatory power of the model adopted.

sec.title: Variables and operationalization
sec.p: This analysis of interdependence theory focuses on varying levels of political relations that exist between China and its neighbours. The International Cooperation and Regional Conflicts dataset is used to measure interstate political relations until 1997, and the author conducted a content analysis from 1997 to 2001 from the New York Times to extend the dataset using the same methodology.51 Individual events from widely available news sources were measured up and down a conflict–cooperation continuum based on categories of interaction implying levels of conflict or cooperation using codes of discrete interactions developed from the World Events Interaction Survey.52 Data is then weighted to create a continuous variable. Weights for the data can be found in Goldstein.53 For instance, breaking of diplomatic ties is weighted a -7 while extending economic aid is a 7.4. Based on the start date of the event, the dependent variable is an average level of political relations calculated for each dyad-year from 3,272 events during the research time frame. The sample mean value for interstate political relations is 0.374, while the range is [-10,6.5].54

Figure 1 shows the annual trend of mean political relations between China and its more-developed neighbours – Japan, Russia, and South Korea. Relations with South Korea and Russia have generally been positive since the Tiananmen Square incident in 1989. However, political relations with Japan remain volatile. Figure 2 shows the annual trend of mean political relations between China and its less-developed neighbours. As one might expect, Sino-Pakistani political relations have remained positive, while Sino-Filipino relations have been generally negative. Chinese political relations with India and Vietnam have improved since 1994.

sec.p: While the central predictor of interest is economic interdependence, early measurements of economic interdependence were drawn from international trade statistics. These empirical studies used international trade as the sole measurement of economic interdependence.55 This measurement is used because interstate trade creates benefits to both states, otherwise the transaction would not occur. A state’s objective through interstate trade is the improvement of national welfare and the allocation of resources through internal development and trade. States begin to rely on these benefits as certain segments of society prosper from these gains. Moreover, states benefit from the increased production of their goods for export and from retailers that import goods states themselves cannot produce as efficiently as their import partners. Faced with the prospect of losing trade with a partner should war break out, a state is less likely to choose the war option with these trading states since its opportunity costs are increased. Trading states recognize that they can do better through internal economic development sustained by a worldwide market for their goods and services than by attempting to conquer and assimilate large tracts of land.56

While international trade is often used as a proxy for interdependence, there is no consensus in the literature as to how to operationalize this variable.57 Trade interdependence is measured primarily by two methods. It is measured as a state’s bilateral trade relative to both its GDP (economy–trade interdependence) and its world trade (partner–trade interdependence). Adopting separate measures accommodates two needs. First, while these two indicators are highly correlated, they may in fact vary inversely for some states. Second, adopting two different bases allows for comparison of the measurements employed. Since there is no uniform measurement for how trade interdependence is calculated, some results may be an artefact of measurement.

Using two estimates provides distinct measurements of dyadic trade interaction; however, these two measurements are highly correlated, though at times they may produce divergent estimates of trade interdependence, especially when a state’s trade partner accounts for a large portion of the state’s total trade but a relatively small amount compared to its GDP. For instance, Myanmar’s trade with China in 1989 was US$314m and its world trade that year was US$409m. Trade with China accounted for roughly 77 per cent of Myanmar’s total trade. Myanmar’s GDP in 1989 was US$5,800m, resulting in its trade with China accounting for 5.4 per cent of its GDP. As a result of this asymmetry, the dyadic economy–trade interdependence score is 0.052 while the dyadic partner–trade interdependence score is 0.44. The literature on interdependence has not settled the debate on which economic indicator is more appropriate.58 Therefore, this research adopts both in the analyses.

As the unit of analysis for this research is a dyad, it is necessary to construct a truly dyadic measure of trade interdependence between pairs of states. To construct this, a partner dependence measure is calculated. Partner dependence is equal to dyadic trade divided by GDP for a given state. This is calculated for both China and its neighbour at time t. The partner dependence scores are summed and then divided by 1 plus the absolute value of the difference of the two scores.59 State i’s partner dependence value is the first term in the numerator and state j’s partner dependence value is the second term in the numerator.

States can find alternate trading partners during times of conflict, though they may incur additional costs. States, however, cannot move FDI from the host country without incurring substantial, prohibitive costs to its FDI. A state may engage in FDI for two reasons: market expansion and lower production costs. Both forms of FDI involve actors from a home state investing money in a host state. The actor from the home state stands to lose its investment should relations between the two states spiral into conflict. The host state, while able to seize control of the investment, stands to lose future investments not only from the home state but also other states because the introduction of instability renders increasingly difficult risk-factor calculations. These factors lead both the home and the host state to prefer to settle disputes pacifically to maintain their current and future investments.61

Suffice it to say, data had to be transformed to satisfy the assumptions of linear regression analysis. Data was evaluated to ensure that assumptions for regression analysis were met as completely as possible. This evaluation led to the transformation of the three independent variables to reduce skewness and kurtosis, improve normality, linearity, and homoscedasticity of residuals. A cube root transformation was used on the three interdependence measures.

A key assumption in economic interdependence theory is that state actors are rational and seek to maximize their utility. As such according to the theory, state leaders who make decisions affecting their interstate political relations will take into account their economic position with other states. Since a statesperson cannot be certain what the economic position will be in the current year or future years, the best estimate is the previous year’s economic relationship. Therefore, economic interdependence variables are lagged one year so that any given mean political relation is being explained by economic indicators from the preceding year. Additionally, lagging the independent variables eliminates effects that changes in political relations may have on trade and financial flows, and thus affect the level of economic interdependence.

Table 1 displays the average annual bilateral trade with China for 10 of its neighbours included in this analysis. While Japan remains the largest trading partner among this group of states, it is noteworthy to point out that Sino-South Korean average annual bilateral trade increased more than tenfold over these two time frames. Additionally, several other smaller economies increased their average bilateral trade with China by tenfold or more, namely, India, Vietnam, and Cambodia.

Along with measurements of interdependence, the following effects are controlled for in this study: partner democracy, peace years, relative power, military expenditure (as a percentage of GDP), participation in Asian institutions and regimes, and per capita gross national income (GNI).

sec.title: Partner democracy
sec.p: There is abundant empirical research showing that democracies refrain from war with one another.63 Since China is not a democracy, there would be no use in employing a joint democratic indicator. Less observed are the pacific relations of democracies towards non-democracies. Some studies have found that the more libertarian a state is the less it experiences foreign violence.64 As such, this study controls for the effects of a neighbouring state’s level of democracy on its interstate relations with China. This study uses the Institutional Democracy Index and the Autocracy Index from the Polity IV dataset to create an ordinal variable, with range [-11,11], for overall level of democracy for each state in a dyad with China, and for each year to control for the effects democracy may have on interstate relations.65 The democracy and autocracy scores, each measured on an 11-point scale, are used in the Polity IV dataset to measure each government’s openness to citizen participation, degree of competition in the recruitment of potential candidates for election to office, and the degree of institutional checks available in the exercise of power within the state in a given year. Each state’s autocracy score is subtracted from its democracy score for an overall measurement of democracy.66
Summary democracy scores are shown in Table 2, indicating that South Korea, Japan, India, and the Philippines are China’s main democratic neighbours.

sec.title: Peace years
sec.p: A control variable called peace years is created to reflect the number of years a dyad has remained at peace with one another. The number of consecutive years a dyad maintains a positive value for mean political conflict should be positively related to cooperation according to the logic that the longer the period of time a dyad is at peace the more likely it is to remain at peace.

sec.title: Relative power capabilities and military expenditures
sec.p: Relative power capabilities are controlled for because these capabilities have received much attention in conflict studies. Empirical studies confirm that a preponderance of power promotes peace.67 This study operationalizes relative power by evaluating relative capabilities available to each state in a given dyad. Correlates of War Composite Index of National Capabilities (COW CINC) scores are used to measure each state’s share of the interstate system’s total military, industrial, and demographic resources. The log of the ratio of China’s capabilities to each of its neighbours is used to measure relative power in a given year. Furthermore, a control variable measuring the partner state’s military expenditure relative to its GDP is created. High levels of military expenditure may indicate a hostile environment and increase the likelihood of conflict within the dyad. Data for military expenditure was obtained from the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI).

Relative power capability summary scores are shown in Table 3, indicating that Japan, India, Russia, and South Korea ranked as having greater relative power than China, while Pakistan had nearly identical relative power.

sec.title: Institutional participation
sec.p: Institutions in East Asia help to foster extensive economic linkages between members and provide an outlet for discussion and debate among its members, increasing communication between states. Bremer finds that national alliances incur less conflict among members than among non-members.68 For example, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) has successfully kept residual conflicts between members, especially territorial disputes, quiet. However, the intergovernmental organizations in Asia are not formal alliances, generally do not create any binding obligations for members, and produce policy that reflects ‘a lowest common denominator’.69 In spite of these assertions, since ASEAN’s creation, armed confrontation has been avoided among its members despite more than a dozen territorial conflicts among them. Additionally, communication variables tend to be positively related to interstate conflict.70 A dummy variable has been created to capture periods when states were members of the following institutions with China: Chiang Mai Initiative, ASEAN Plus Three, ASEAN Regional Forum, Shanghai Cooperation Organization, and bilateral agreements. A dyad is given a value of one for each organization it participates in each year, and then these values are summed.

Summary scores, shown in Table 4, indicate that Asian states had few common institutional memberships with China until 1994. Thereafter, Japan shared an average of three common institutional memberships with China each year, followed by Russia, Vietnam, Cambodia, the Philippines, and other states.

sec.title: Economic development
sec.p: Lastly, levels of economic development are controlled for in this study by using per capita gross national income from the Polity IV dataset to indicate levels of successful economies. States enjoying successful economies are less apt to fight for fear of disrupting current economic trends. Furthermore, regimes may have an incentive to distract attention from a declining economy.71

sec.title: Empirical results
sec.p: Three standard multiple regressions were performed between mean political relations and economy–trade interdependence, partner–trade interdependence, and financial interdependence separately with all six control variables.

Table 5 displays the results of the three models. From the adjusted R2 term, the findings indicate that, on average, each model explains approximately 31 per cent of the variation in interstate political relations with China, and that the overall fit differs very little across models.

caption.p: Multivariate regression models for the prediction of interstate political relations, 1987–2001.

sec.p: The regression coefficients for economy–trade interdependence, partner–trade interdependence, and peace years are significant and point in a consistent direction across all models where available. Relative power capabilities, while significant in only the first of these three models, point in a consistently negative direction.

Model 1 tests the first hypothesis: as economy–trade interdependence increases, interstate political relations improve. Model 1 shows that economy–trade interdependence is associated with improving political relations between China and its neighbours thus supporting the first hypothesis. The regression coefficient for economy–trade interdependence is 6.711 and is significant at the p≤.10 level. Furthermore, when interdependence is measured relative to total trade rather than GDP, as in Model 2, partner–trade interdependence is associated with improving interstate political relations. The regression coefficient for partner–trade interdependence is 5.993 and is significant at the p≤.10 level. Thus, the second hypothesis is also supported.

Model 3 tests the third hypothesis: increases in financial interdependence improve interstate political relations. The findings here do not confirm the third hypothesis because financial interdependence does not significantly relate to improving interstate political relations. While the regression coefficient for financial interdependence is positive –.990 – it fails to reach statistical significance.

Several other interesting findings should be pointed out. First, the regression coefficient for peace years is positive and significant in all three models. This consistency supports the idea that peace breeds peace; that is, the greater the number of consecutive years that a state has cooperation with China, the more likely improved interstate relations will follow. Second, the regression coefficient for relative power capabilities is negative in all three models and is significant in the first model. This consistency indicates that, as China’s power grows relative to its neighbours’ power, there is a higher likelihood of conflict within the dyad. These two variables, where significant, have a larger impact on mean political relations than both economy–trade interdependence and partner–trade interdependence.

sec.title: Discussion of research results
sec.p: Which variables have the largest impact on political relations between China and its neighbours? Regression coefficients can indicate the extent of the impact of an independent variable on the dependent variable. Comparing the magnitude of the regression coefficients requires reducing them to a common standard. In the first model where economy–trade interdependence is significant, despite the large regression coefficient value relative to the others (6.711 for economy–trade interdependence compared to 0.593 for peace years and -1.29 for relative power capabilities), its impact on the dependent variable is small relative to the impact caused by the other two variables that also reach significance. Table 6 indicates that by holding the other independent variables constant and manipulating economy–trade interdependence by its hinge spread, its impact on mean political relations is 1.05 whereas relative power capabilities have an impact of -1.26, and peace years have an impact of 1.78 when, all things constant, a state moves from the first quartile value of the variable to the third quartile value.72

All things equal, as a state moves from a low level of interdependence with China at the first quartile value to a higher level at the third quartile value, the result is an increase of 1.05 on improved political relations between this state and China. The impact of relative power capabilities and peace years is 20 per cent and 70 per cent greater, respectively. Even where significant, therefore, economy–trade interdependence appears to make less of a contribution to dyadic cooperation than other factors.

caption.p: Impact of independent variables on interstate political relations.

sec.p: Table 7 assesses the impact that partner–trade interdependence has on mean interstate political relations. This table uses results from the second model where partner–trade interdependence reaches significance, along with peace years. Contrary to the first model, relative power capabilities do not reach statistical significance in the second model. In this model a state moving from the first quartile range of partner–trade interdependence to the third quartile range has an impact of 1.15 on the dependent variable, whereas the impact that peace years has on mean political relations is 1.61, 40 per cent greater than that of partner–trade interdependence.

caption.p: Impact of independent variables on interstate political relations.

sec.p: Does economy–trade or partner–trade interdependence have a greater effect on improving political relations with China? Comparing Table 6 with Table 7 reveals that increases in partner–trade interdependence produce slightly more benefits to cooperation than increases in economy–trade interdependence, approximately 9.5 per cent greater. States cannot, however, independently increase their partner–trade interdependence with China because increases must result in a decline for some other state. Additionally, while developing states may promote their exports to China, they may not be able to afford increases in Chinese imports. Developed states, on the other hand, may be able to buy more Chinese goods to increase their partner–trade interdependence, but the Chinese may not be able to increase their imports from the developed economy. Both situations produce gains in economy–trade interdependence, as long as the increases are greater than increases in GDP, but do not necessarily result in gains in partner–trade interdependence. What level of economy–trade interdependence must occur for a dyad to experience the same benefits to cooperation that partner–trade interdependence provides?

The benefits to cooperation provided by trade interdependence are equalized at the 77th percentile of economy–trade interdependence and the third quartile of partner–trade interdependence. This is found by solving for the required hinge spread that would create an impact on mean interstate political relations equal to 1.15 (the benefits provided by partner–trade interdependence as a dyad moves from the first to the third quartile level of interdependence).73 A dyad must experience 13.8 per cent more economy–trade interdependence than the third quartile value when moving from the first quartile in order to experience equivalent benefits to political cooperation that arise when a dyad moves from the first to the third quartile values of partner-trade interdependence. In sum, increases in partner–trade interdependence are associated with slight increases in political cooperation relative to increases in economy–trade interdependence. However, increases in the former cannot occur without an equivalent reduction among China’s other trading partners; whereas increases in the latter may occur independent of these other states.

The benefits to cooperation are shown to be nearly equivalent regardless of whether a state increases its economy–trade interdependence or partner–trade interdependence. Can gains in economy–trade interdependence be offset by increases in China’s relative power? The costs associated with a state advancing from a first quartile value of economic interdependence and relative power capabilities are not equal. Looking at the corresponding economic interdependence level and relative power capabilities will provide some insight into how much a state actually changes along these variables in order to experience the pacifying benefits provided by economic interdependence.

Looking at an actual case from the dataset will aid in understanding the dynamics associated with varying levels of trade interdependence and relative power capabilities. Cambodia is useful for just this purpose. Figure 3 displays the average annual level of political relations between China and Cambodia from 1993 to 2000. These years were chosen specifically because the Sino-Cambodian dyad moved from the first quartile to the third quartile value for economy–trade interdependence during this period. The first and third quartile values of economy–trade interdependence are 0.0099 and 0.0514 respectively. In 1993 Cambodia had an economy–trade interdependence value of 0.0091, a value that is very close to the first quartile value. By 2000, Sino-Cambodian interdependence grew to 0.0578, again, a value that is very close to the third quartile value. Subsequently, political cooperation improved on average two units per year across this time frame. It is also worth noting that Cambodia’s GDP increased by over 43 per cent during this time frame highlighting the benefits to the overall economy aided by increases in economy–trade interdependence with China.

In contrast to the benefits to political cooperation created by increases in economy–trade interdependence are the deteriorations to political relations created by increases in China’s relative power capabilities. Composite Index of National Capability (CINC) data from the Correlates of War dataset indicates that China’s share of world power increased from roughly 10.8 per cent to 13.4 per cent over the period 1987–2001. However, relative to the states in the sample for this research, China’s relative power increased for only four states: Japan, Mongolia, Russia, and Vietnam. The other six states experienced power increases relative to China.

Table 6 shows that as a dyad moves from the first quartile value of relative power capabilities to the third quartile, it experiences, on average, a deterioration in interstate political relations by the order of 1.26 units. Because the log of relative power capabilities is used in the regression analysis to normalize the data, it is necessary to return to the original values for relative power. The first and third quartile values for relative power capabilities are 2.2 and 21.2 respectively. These values represent dyads where China’s share of world power is about twice greater and 21 times greater than that of its partners, respectively. The third quartile is roughly 10 times greater than the first quartile value, indicating that a dyad moving from the first quartile value to the third quartile would require the partner state to shift from being roughly half as powerful as China to one-twentieth times as powerful. This extreme shift can occur principally through two mechanisms: power increases by China or power decreases by the partner state. As indicated previously, China’s share of world power increased by 2.6 per cent from 1987 to 2001. This increase represents a rate of 24 per cent over the 15-year time frame. A 24 per cent increase cannot account for the increase of a factor of 10 needed to move the dyad to the third quartile. As such, the partner state must also undergo a decline in its share of world power to approximately the magnitude of an eighth of its current power, equivalently an 87.5 per cent decline. No states exist within the sample whose share of world power decreased to roughly one-eighth of its previous size at any time.

The foregoing analysis illustrates the rare occurrence of a state increasing its relative power by a factor of 10. As China increased its share of world power by 24 per cent, its military expenditures increased from US$6.7 billion in 1987 to US$46 billion in 2001, a 587 per cent increase. On average, an increase of 10 per cent of China’s military expenditure produced only an increase of 0.41 per cent of its share of world power. Certainly there are diminishing returns on the influence that military expenditures have on world power share. For instance, in 1991 China increased its military expenditure by 210 per cent over the previous year but only experienced a 6 per cent increase in its share of world power rather than the 8.6 per cent that would be expected if no diminishing occurred.

In closing, while increases in relative power capabilities produce a deterioration in political relations between China and its neighbours, relative power shifts are costly and occur gradually. No dyad from 1987 to 2001 experienced a shift in relative power capabilities from the first quartile value to the third quartile. Furthermore, while China’s share of world power has increased during the study’s time frame, its relative power has only increased for four states. Though increases in economy–trade interdependence produce fewer benefits to cooperation relative to the reduction in political relations brought on by relative power increases, increasing economy–trade interdependence is beneficial to the overall economy and therefore costs less than balancing relative power increases.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In conclusion there are several significant findings related to the effects of economic interdependence on interstate political relations. First, economy–trade interdependence and partner–trade interdependence are consistent with the hypothesis that as interdependence increases, the likelihood of conflict decreases.74 The impact, however, that both economy– and partner–trade interdependence have on mean interstate relations is less than the impact that relative power capabilities and peace years have where significant. This demonstrates support for realist assertions that political–military issues dominate interstate relations where power relations underlie any apparent effect interdependence may have on interstate relations. Second, financial interdependence between China and its neighbours does not have a statistically significant effect on interstate political relations. Lastly, measurements of interdependence based on GDP and total trade show a similar impact on interstate relations between China and its neighbours, which helps bridge the gap in interdependence measurements.

These conclusions have important implications. First, as neoliberals such as Polachek, Rosecrance, and Keohane and Nye have previously demonstrated, increases in trade interdependence can lead to improvements in interstate political relations even among China and its neighbours, but other factors should not be ignored. This result only holds if power differences are not occurring. As realists such as Mearsheimer and Waltz note, relative power increases by China can lead to a deterioration in interstate political relations with its neighbours. These results show that increases in China’s relative power are associated with decreases in dyadic political relations that are greater than the extent to which trade interdependence can improve these relations. This means that to maintain or increase cooperation, relative power capabilities need to remain stable.

The current situation in East Asia is mixed. Globalization has resulted in reduced restrictions on trade and FDI, facilitating increases in interdependence between China and its neighbours. China’s military, however, is gaining strength as current plans include efforts to build an aircraft carrier and general military modernization. China’s military has also recently ascended to the rank of the second largest military budget in the world. If increases in trade interdependence do not follow the increases in power disparities between China and its neighbours, then military balancing will likely be needed in order to maintain cooperation. Yet, some prospect for peace exists. Since interdependence is related to peace, it is therefore related to peace years. Changing relative power capabilities is a more costly means to achieve cooperation than increasing levels of economic interdependence.

This research does not find the relationship between interstate political relations and financial interdependence to be statistically significant. Further research should continue to address the area of financial interdependence because the growth of FDI into China continues to expand during a time when China is beginning to enter the outward FDI arena itself. Compared to trade, the contributions to the growth of FDI are relatively limited to a much smaller subset of players in East Asia (and the world for that matter). Only seven economies in East Asia had an outward FDI greater than US$1 billion in 2006.75 China’s ability to capture global FDI has led to its place as the world’s top recipient in 2002, ahead of the United States.76 In 2006, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, and Hong Kong accounted for over 88 per cent of inward Chinese FDI originating in Asia. While a substantial portion of inward FDI into China originates from within China and is routed through Hong Kong or Macao, or some other Free Port Island, the number of other Asian economies with over US$1 billion of FDI in China remains limited to just four: South Korea, Japan, Taiwan, and Singapore. In 2004 seven Asian economies according to level of China’s FDI investment (Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, Russia, Indonesia, Brunei, and India) accounted for more than 90 per cent of China’s Asian inward FDI apart from the big six players’ investment (Hong Kong, South Korea, Japan, Taiwan, Singapore, and Macao). Malaysia and the Philippines led this group with 31 per cent and 19 per cent of this FDI respectively.77 This group of seven has increased their FDI into China by 77 per cent from 2003 to 2006, amounting to nearly US$1.2 billion in 2006. Recent trends suggest that these nations are becoming significant players in China’s FDI arena, thus increasing their financial interdependence with China over time.

A consensus measurement for trade interdependence in related interdependence literature does not exist. This research uses two of the most commonly found bases for trade interdependence: GDP and total trade. The findings show that trade interdependence measurements based on total trade produce similar outcomes to measurements based on GDP. This finding is not surprising since these indicators are highly correlated. However, this finding increases prospects for peace in East Asia because states that may experience a decline in interdependence with China due to a reduction in relative partner trade may experience an increase in interdependence based on GDP growth. Even though a trading partner of China may become less significant relative to China’s other trading partners, it may still experience increases in trade relative to its GDP. These increases in economy–trade interdependence facilitate peace as well. As states compete for a larger stake of China’s trade, competition intensifies. This could create the conditions for conflict. The results show, however, that growth in trade relative to GDP can offset this potential conflict and lead to cooperation.

In conclusion, this research provides support for the unconditional liberal hypothesis, helping to bridge international relations theories with Chinese foreign policy. Regardless of how trade interdependence is measured, this relationship holds. Further, among relations between China and its neighbours, financial interdependence is not statistically significant in improving interstate political relations. Although trade interdependence is significantly related to improving interstate relations, other factors have a greater impact on conflict, such as the number of consecutive years of peace within a dyad and relative power capabilities.

Further statistical research might include additional measures of interdependence such as measures of production interdependence, the degree to which China and its neighbours are interdependently linked through various production and supply chains in East Asia. These linkages have become more common in relevant literature. The importance of evaluating this phenomenon has been highlighted by Brooks.78 Extensive international production networks exist throughout East Asia as many of the goods produced are exported from Southeast Asian nations to China for assembly where they are then exported to consumers primarily in developed economies. Analysing each economy’s dependencies on these networks and their contribution of the value added to each good would further the understanding of the economic motivations for peace in East Asia.

Additionally, Oneal et al. do not use absolute value, but instead order the terms from high value to low value to avoid a negative difference in the denominator.

Absolute value is used in the denominator so that the effect of any asymmetries within a dyad produces a consistent reducer effect regardless of the direction of the asymmetry. For instance, without the use of absolute value, if i’s dependence on j is less than j’s dependence on i then the denominator will have a multiplier effect on the numerator. If i’s dependence on j is greater than j’s dependence on i then the denominator will have a reducer effect on the numerator. Since the designation of which actor is i and which is j is arbitrary, a uniform direction is necessary for all dyads. Adopting the absolute value in the denominator will create a consistent reducer effect across all dyads.
